Minimal soapy noble hops, just enough to balance it out.  Some light buttery tones, probably old lines.  Light to medium body.  A little thin and one-d.  Macro, some corny tastes.  OK.
Pours clear yellow with thin white lacing. Light musky aroma with yeast notes. Thin palate with some metallic notes. OK drinking. Not a great lager but better than Budwieser.

Pours a crystal clear light golden colour with a normal white head that diminishes quickly.
Aroma is simple with the classic german mixture of cereal malts, bread and grassy hops. Maybe a slight pineapple note is the only important difference.
Taste is agreeable with a reasonable bitterness and almost no sweetness. A crisp Helles showing the Reinheitsgebot with proud. If you are expecting something stronger then you grabbed the wrong beer.
Light bodied and refreshing. Very ahead of the typical macro lager but not my favorite style at all.

12/1/11. 12oz bottle... how on earth have I not rated this? Well, here goes. Clear golden pour with a small soapy off-white head that fades quickly to a film and barely laces at all in small, soapy rings. Skunk in the aroma first and foremost, followed by lots of sweetness and corn chips. Skunk in the flavor as well followed by bitter, dry pale malts and more lingering sweet corn. Blllleeech.

one of the better helles in my opinion. I had it from the tap in Munich. Grassy and hay aroma. Taste was well balanced with malt and hops. Good "party" beer if you ask me since it’s not so filling as the wheat beers. Very enjoyable.
This is the best german beer available in bottles in my area.  The beer is a great beer to introduce to beer drinkers who have a fear of trying imports.

Bottle centra carrigart. poured from bottle into a pint glass. Nice clean pint with germanys puriety laws. a little spice & minerally hoppiness over a clean crisp pils malt base.  nice bottle, been meaning to try it for awhile now, cheap enough too here in ireland. would have again.

Nice white head, clear golden color, good lager smell, crisp and clean, mild malt and yeast flavor.  Just OK.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
5.2%, gold with no head, a disappointing beer, I should have known better that try a this type of beer, must have been seduced by the nice bottle.

Appearance: sunny, clear golden with a one-finger fizzy white head slowly shrinking.   Aroma: cereal, grass, hay, spritz of lemon.   Taste: buttery white bread, some cracked pepper, notes of cheerios and a hint of lemon.   Finish: short, crisp, clean, and just a bit grassy/peppery.   Notes: As far as German lagers go, this is one of them.  Way better than its American counterparts.  Seemed like more of a pilsner than a dortmunder or helles.  Lively yet drinkable palate.  I do prefer the Paulaner take on this style.

pours clear golden with a decent head, very little retention and lacing. cereals, corn, wheat, hint of sweetness, light herbal-grass notes, light lemon. aggressive carbonation, light body, short boring finish.

500 ml. botte. Clear yellow colour, big head that does’nt hold much, but leaves a ring on the surface. Smell  of lemon, grain, slightly fruity. Fresh and crispy palate, taste is herbal, lemon. Not a omplex beer, but very drinkable and enjoyable. Good one.

Can [500ml]. Pours a pale bubbly gold with a small diminishing fizzy white head. Aroma is sweet and floral along with grassy hops and pale malt. Mild but decent flavour of light grassy hops, slightly floral, along with pale malt and an average, short bitter finish. Average bodied. Nothing exciting but it’s easy enough to drink and would be pleasant on a warm summer day.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Chiara, testa bianca, media, aroma lievemente erbaceo, luppolatura elegante al naso, ma un pò anonima, in bocca è maltosa, finale un pò più amaro, ma poco accattivante, una hell precisa e puntuale. ma non esaltante.

Very pale golden pour.  The nose is lovely - spicy/minerally hoppiness over a clean crisp pils malt base.  The aroma has a nice balance of soft lightly zesty character over a fresh pale maltiness.  Clean and crisp.  Firm palate with a nice crackery maltiness.  Firm carbonate bitterness with a lingering clean hoppiness. Solid brew really - at a toonie a can, it’s tough to beat the value.
500 ml can from LCBO.  Pours blonde in colour, with smallish white head.  Aroma and taste are nicely slightly sweet malt and a hint of Euro hops.  Good!

500ml can.  Pours a clear gold, with a good sized white head.  The aroma is sweet malt, metallic hops, yeast and citrus.  Taste wise, there are more malt notes than you usually find in Euro-lagers, nicely balanced with a medium hoppy finish.  Very easy drinking, and recommended.  As far as lagers go, there is nothing to complain about here.
can.  Poured clear gold with a receding white head. Grassy hop aroma. Crisp carbonated mouthfeel. Pale malt flavour with some medium bitter perfumey hop notes. Finish is medium dry and bitter.

Ein herb-würziger Geruch steigt aus dem Testglas. Geschmacklich geht es dann auch würzig weiter, wobei sich Herbe und Malzigkeit gut die Waage halten. 
Dieses Helle hat mir gut geschmeckt. Erwartete ich doch höchstens Mittelmaß. Positive Überraschung.Test vom 17.3.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche
Bottle 50cl a clear yellow beer with medium head. Nose is vegetable like. Aroma is medium malty, dry, peppery hops with grassy notes, basic.

Tysk Helles, ljus till färgen stort skum som långsamt lägger sig till ett lock. Frisk, lite maltig doft. Smaken är mycket lätt, liten maltsötma, friskt, men tyvärr inte mycket humle. Ganska anonym och tråkig.

Bottle. Pours a clean gold with a white head, was a decent sized head but disappeared very quickly. Has a light, grassy aroma, really not much to it. Has a grassy flavor too, weak hops and a bit tinny. Not a big fan of this, but it isn’t horrible. 5.2% alcohol.

Tap at some bar in Milano,
Aroma is malty earthy, flowery. Hazy yellow w white head and lots of lacing. Flavor is too sweet for me. Some citrus and earthy malty flowery taste as well. Light-medium body w avg carbonation. I can drink this but won’t really enjoy it.
Pours a pale light golden color.  Aroma is of dusty malts, malts, some hops, and corn.  Flavor is of malts, sweeter hops, cereal, aluminum, and corn.  Leaves a dusty malt finish.  Nothing special.

Very clear wheat gold pour with a light vigorous head.  Grassy nose.  Somewhat bitter bite in the mouth at first that fades to a sweet aftertaste.  Very different mix of tastes.  Can’t decide how much I like or dislike it.  I don’t like the bitterness but the swap to sweet is somewhat pleasant but then the sweetness is too much.  Low carbonation.  Interesting but I probably wouldn’t buy it again.

(Draught at Hilpeä Hauki, 20110827) The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had grass, metallicness and sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with quite high carbonation. Flavours were grass, sweetness, grain, malts and bitterness. Aftertaste was bitter. Clean and dull pale lager.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 130406
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.

Very subtle aromas, soft cracker/bread and very low hop presence. Pale gold with great clarity. Malt forward flavor, sweet with subtle bitterness and spice. Clean and delicate. Short aftertaste. Crisp and smooth.

500ml can 

5.2% ABV 

I tried this beer on August 5, 2011 after purchasing from one of my local LCBO outlets.  The beer poured a translucent light gold with a short-lived generous white head.  The aroma was was biscuit malt, some yeast, and a floral hoppish sense.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied, with medium carbonation.  The flavour was nicely balanced between the malt and hops.  No excess sweetness whatsoever.
On draft.  Classic example of the style.  A little grainy but very smooth.  Golden color with a white head.

Very light and clear straw-colored body. Head is a thin white skiff. Classic "beer" aroma, which includes mild notes of cardboard, hay, grass, and lemon. Taste is standard light lager refreshment, clean and simple. This version of the style is especially well balanced with zesty hops. Decent brew but nothing extraordinary.

500ml can, 5.2% a/v

Very light gold colour with a nice white head. Aroma is classic pils for what i smell, hoppy and a bit of malt (have a stuffy nose, may be missing alot here). Taste is maltier than the smell but balanced very well by the hops. This is indeed a very well balanced beer, I am impressed!

Bottle from Systembolaget.
pours pale yellow with a white head.
Simle beer, typical german maltyness and hops
(This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)

Canned sample. Pale gold in colour with strong carbonation. Aromas are of clean pilsner malt, white bread, wet stones, and a bit of green floral hop. Light bodied in the mouth with a clean and basic crispy pale malt and mineral flavour composition. There’s a small hint of hop on the back end too. Well executed, yet nothing special either.

0,5 l. bottle from Systembolaget. Crystal clear golden colour with a small white head, that fades quikly. Aroma is yeasts, malts and a hint of hops. Overall this beer has a mild taste and a light sweetness. Finish leaves a grainy maltiness. Nothing special, but a light (in taste, not alcohol!), refreshing beer for a hot summer day.
On tap in Munich. Clean and golden colour. Kind of characterless flavour, but not too bad.
500 mL glass at Spaten place in Munich.  Good head, golden with a bit of fizz.  Light malty aroma.  Its quite reasonable.
can, pours a bright pale yellow, smell very corny like and the taste was pretty dry and had a ruff taste, wasnt a huge a fan, thanks for the share

Tap: pours a pale clear gold (Lightest of the Munich Hells) with a decent 2 finger puffy white cap. Peppery carbonation.

Aroma is somewhat demure - sweet malts with noble earthy tones

A fairly straight forward German lager but superbly balanced between light bready malt sweetness and noble hop depth. Medium bodied with a Crisp clean lightly dry finish with a distinct bready after taste. Probably the best of the Munich Hell lagers. No way to confuse this with the lighter, sharper hoppier Pils.
Can. Poured clear light yellow with small head that fades quickly. Not muuch body. Smooth, crisp finish.

A clear, light gold pour with a white head.  It has lightly sweet, cereal aroma.  The light body has a thin texture with average carbonation.  The taste is mildly sweet with just a touch of bitterness appearing in the finish.

500 ml can from LCBO.  Pours a clear golden yellow with small white head.  Aroma is lightly sweet grains and grass.  Flavour is crisp with grains and a more pronounced grassiness that gives some bitterness to the finish.  Better than a lot of the LCBO’s Euro lagers but not really all that special.

500ml can from the lhiyckboe. Bright yellow gold with a small white frothy head. Aroma is plain pale malts with tinny hops. Flavour is better with some nice Noble hop character underneath the plain pils and pale malt body. Very effervescent and prickly on the palate in a refreshing way. A very pedestrian offering but the price is right and it’s nice to finally have something from that other Munich brewery.

500ml can from the liquor control board of ontario. 
Very pale yellow pour with a small quickly disapearing head. Crisp cereal grains, grassy hops. Grassy hop flavor with some solid malt. Soft medium bitter finish with a very slight apple aftertaste. My taste buds say meh.
500ml can from the lcbo. canned 29 days ago, pretty impressive. easy drinking all malt light lager. run of the mill stuff, doesnt have the softness i expect from a helles.
tall boy can. not much too it. very light body, some hops. drinkable and not offensive.

Can from the LCBO- Sparkling gold with a moderate fizzy white cap. Some lacing left behind. Nose of pale malts, biscuit, lemon, straw. Mildly bitter, grassy, pale malt and doughy sweetness comes in as well. Light bodied, medium carbonation. Grassy and biscuity finish is nice. A good Helles/Dort.

500 ml can from LCBO, served cold in a tulip glass. 



App.:  Clear golden with a small white head.
  
Aroma:  Cereals/grains, some biscuit, some of what I’d call “typical” green, peppery German hopping, an odd sweet note, a little dusty/musty.
  
Palate:  Medium body, restrained carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Cereals/grains and biscuit take a backseat to cardboard, much less of the hop notes, little else; dry with moderate bitterness and a not unpleasant biscuity, peppery finish.



Drinkable.  More or less.

Bottle.
Pale yellow with a white head. 
This is going to sound strange: shellfish, lemons, corn,grass, sweet and bready malt.
Medium-bodied with a high carbonation.
Not especially good.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a Red Sox World Series 2007 Champions pint glass.

The color is a light yellow and has about two fingers of foamy white head that is gone pretty quickly but leaves little hints of lacing left on the glass.

The smell is a bit of toasty malt aroma that is a little like butter on dry toast. There is a peanut brittle aroma as well.

The taste is has crispy malt flavor that is a little biscuit mixed with fried dough. The same peanut brittle like flavor comes back as I inhale while tasting a sip. there is a nice sweetness toward the end that has an ever so small bitterness to let you know there is some hops in this beer but this is driven by the malts to it’s destination which is my tongue.

The feel of this beer is pretty crisp and has the signature of a German pilsner. There is a bready aftertaste with some smooth feel as this goes down. A well made larger that would got well with some pulled pork.
This beer is a pleasant surprise, pure light color, flavor with a pleasant mouth spreads after, smell clean, pleasant beer refreshing
Bottle. This beer is all about sweet malts. It’s not bad, but i would have liked some kind of hop bitterness... or anything really, to make it a little more complex and drinkable.

Spaten Premium Lager has a thin-to-medium white head and a clear, yellow-golden appearance, with some bubbles and not much lacing. The aroma (not skunked, thankfully- green bottle) is strong, bready malt, with a bit of clean water and a dash of hops. Taste is likewise very bready and the bitter hops really add zing to this one. Mouthfeel is light and watery, and Spaten Premium Lager finishes crisp, clean, refreshing, and mostly dry. Overall, this is a very good beer, and I think you’ll enjoy it.

RJT

bottle.  Pours a pale clear gold with finger of white froth.  Aroma of buttered corn, grass, straw.  Medium bodied, clean, refreshing, crisp, smooth.  Flavor is light and grassy with somewhat of a watery finish.  A little less body than some of my favorite dortmunders.  Still, not a bad example of the style.  You could have called it a kolsch and fooled me honestly.  Anyway, miles beyond budweiser.
500 ml bottle a golden yellow colored beer with a white head aroma malts grassy hops flavor malts water and grassy hops

12 oz. from a variety pack @ Binny’s poured into a 16 oz. shaker.



Aroma:   Some grassy notes, with almost a metallic smell present.


Appearance: Straw yellow, with slight sudsy head that disappears quickly.  Looks like Budweiser in the glass.



Taste: Grassy.  Metallic.  Just not very good.  A taste that I associate with some of the really poor pilseners.



Palate: Nice carbonation to the beer.  Makes this otherwise unpleasant beer somewhat palatable.



Overall: This German "Budweiser" is only slightly better than the American edition.  Largely unforgettable.

Pour is a clear yellow with a large fizzy white head.  Aroma is pils malt with some grassy saaz hop.  Flavor is more of a cereal malt with again some grassy hops toward the end.  A no frils dort/helles good for sipping on a Sunday outside.

Frischer, leicht plörriger Geruch. Im Mittelteil leicht würzig, im Nachgeschmack dagegen recht süß. Das Bier wirkt immer mal wieder wässrig, außerdem insgesamt langweilig. Mal ein wenig herb, mal etwas bitter, kann mir besseres vorstellen. 	 
Test vom 21.9.2006, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,8,8,6,7,8 - 7,75

Herber, wenig süßer Antrunk. Hell malzig, etwas Getreide, monoton. Laffe Hopfennoten. 7/7/8/7/6/7

At ’Spatenkeller’ in München. Poured pale golden in colour with foamy white head. Grassy hops, buttery and malty in aroma. Grassy bitterness and malty sweetness (light) in flavour with some metallic notes, which are fortunately not too disturbing.
50 cl, bottled. Pours glear golden with a white head. Aroma: Malt, hops. Taste: Medium sweetness, some bitterness. Malty flavours. Palate: Light bodied, thin/watery. Noticeable carbonation.

50cl bottle. Pours a golden, stead bubbles and a good head. Te nose has pale malt and some faint herby hops. The taste is grassy, herby and mostly drying. The palate is light in structure, then long and refreshing. Overall, this is a very dry, astringent and refreshing lager.

pours clear golden, visible carbonation and short lasting white head.big grain nose.  A mellow flavor, still flavors of grain, corn but more subtle, hint of sweetness.  Smoother finishing but still slightly dry.

8 May 2011, bottle. yellow, clear, steady bubbles, thick foamy white head. smells like a German pils; sweet, barnyard straw and the faintest saaz hops. med/thin body and fizzy. actually a bit heavier in the body than i expected. sweet, malty pils with a dry, bitter hop finish that lingers for a while. nice.
Really nice bear. Good for a hot day. Mild, drinkable balanced cereal malt and hops. Lively carbonation.

Is this green-bottled beer going to be skunky? I would bet my life savings on the answer to that question. 12 oz (?) bottle into lager glass. Pours a clear pale yellow with a small collapsing white head. Aroma is skunk (no way!), wet hayfield. Taste is mostly sweet with a faint bitter hop bite in the finish. Highly carbonated with a medium-thin body. I’m sure this would be pretty good from the tap. Too bad these ancient breweries don’t know (or don’t care) what green glass does to beer.

(bottle) pours a clear pale yellow colour with a frothy white head. aroma of straw and floral hops, with very faint hints of butter, green apple and grain. flavour is quite musty-earthy and cardboardy, with a hint of marzipan and an unfitting light bitter finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Slight head.  Foam clings to the glass. Clear with medium carbonation.  Tastes like like a pilsner with a little little taste or bite.
Bottle - from sampler pack. Light golden color - very clear. Clean, slightly malty aroma. Good balance of malt and hops.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a nice straw color with some lively carbonation and a nice white head. Nose is aromatic with a bit of floral and herbal hops, though mostly light bread and grain. Taste is slightly bitter with some grain and straw. Feel brigs brisk carbonation leading to some pretty good drinkability.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-26-2010

500ml bottle. Very clear and bright with a golden colour and a level loose snow white head. Strong malty aroma with some straw and fresh cut hay mixed in. Full in the mouth with a long lasting bitterness. Almost medicinal tasting.

Tap at their Munich beerhall. Frothy pure white head, clearer golden yellow color. Lagery and light hoppiness in aroma, some creamed corn sneaks in.  Lots of sweetness overpowers any hop presence in the flavor, and very grainy.  Just too sweet, and not good.

Poured into a Warstiener flute. The appearance is exactly what is depicted in the pic, brilliantly clear gold with some effervescence and a fleeting bright white head with fine textured bubbles. Some stingy lacing. The nose is mostly malt driven, with some hints of noble hops and a preferable, light DMS character that delivers the distinctive Munchener Helles character. The flavour is simple and pleasant with a rounded light malt flavour, with impressions of cereal grain, tasty Hallertauer hops, mild DMS, and doughy malt. This beer is insanely attenuated and this comes across in the short, clean finish. The mouthfeel is appropriately light and has a slightly oily texture. It is lower on carbonation that many other examples of the style, which I prefer because for a session beer, harsh carb makes it hard to slam. And this is a slamming beer, plain and simple. A highly perfected example of the style that gets no love because it’s so plain and lightly hopped, but it’s supposed to be! 

I rate to style, bitch!

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a glass mug...

The liquid is a pale golden, yellow with a soapy white head . Smells of hay and skunk with hints of lemon. When you take a sip there is a slightly bitter lemony hop bite with other grassy hop notes and a base of bready malt. It is light with lots of prickly carbonation and it has a dry finish. This is a good German lager, it’s solid all the way around.
Skunky, grassy, and minty, sweet. Clear yellow, medium snow white head. Grainy on the front end, good intensity for the style. Clean, yet subtle finish of mint, tasteful. More Helles than Dortmunder.
Light straw color; Light to medium body; Aroma of malt, & subtle fruit; Flavor of slight sweet malt, hops, grain, and some fruit; Palate is a bit oily; Overall, a bit light - but decent

Esta muy bien balanceada. Probada en Botella en Rochester NY. Tomar bien helada preferiblemente. Muy buen "after taste". Mucho mejor de lo que esperaba. Bastante sabor lupulo que da un gran sabor de media estacion. Un poco de sentido a madera y barrica, refrescante. Buena cerveza.

pours a clear pale gold. Has a skunky spruce aroma. The aroma is stronger than the taste. Has a medium skunky hop taste but finishes lightly sweet and clean. The kind of beer you drink cold on a warm day. Very light body  with a lively finish.
I enjoyed this. Straight forward, malt driven Helles. Not overly complex, with a moderate quenching bitter finish. Solid stuff.
It is a good Munich Helles. You MUST get is fresh though. Without the skunk it is clean with subtle but fresh hop and malt flavors.
On tap, very few lagers can beat this.  Can be very skunky in a bottle, must be had fresh if had in a bottle.

Poured a clear light golden color with a fast fading thin white head. Aroma is light, and a bit grassy.  Taste follows with a grassy touch, and a well balanced but very light body.  Almost a "Helles Light" I would say, except for the obviously higher alcohol content.  Slight metallic twang in the finish that hinders it a bit for me, but it is still a far better brew than any American macro I’ve ever tried.
good malt liquor, imported to US, original from Munich, pale yellow color, light head, low carbonation, light taste, after tingle on back of throat

Pours a lasting ring of white head with a clear, golden body.  Aromas of grain and grass.  Flavor has grain, corn, and grassy notes.  Finish is, once again, grain and grass with a slight dryness.  Well-rounded, clean, easy, session beer.  Would go great with some sushi or Indian food.

I don’t think this is bad.  It isn’t heavy like a lot of beers but manages to quench a thirst quite well.  Clean malt taste tempered by some mild hops.  More refreshing than I expected from the ratings here.
Kinda disappointed in this one especially at 8 bucks a 6 pack.  It was your run of the mill pilsner with no real distinguishing characteristics...no different than any other similar brew,
Colore paglierino con fine schiuma bianca. Aroma tenue di malto. In bocca ancora protagonista il malto, con corpo leggero. Per niente amara.
Bottle.  Weird citrus/resin aroma.  Light texture.  Pretty boring like a lot of German beers.

Crystal clear!!!  Very pale yellow with a super bright white head.  The head was kind of small and didn’t have a tremendous amount of lacing or retention.  Several bubbles working from the bottom to the top.  Reminds me of an American macro in appearance.  A very clean breadiness and cracker like aroma at first that I found enjoyable.  Some fresh "grainy’ or "grassy" hops pull through also.  Not overly complicated.  The grainy hop bitterness comes forth more in the taste.  A touch metallic.  A fresh, dry, white bread type of flavor.  Clean and well balanced.  Medium/thin mouthfeel.  Smooth and crisp.   A bit more dry in the finish than I was expecting.  Seems refreshing.  A bit left on the palate.  This is an ok beer.  I am coming to the conclusion that German Pilsiners and Lagers don’t do much for me.  They are not bad, but just nothing I flip out over.  They are a good change for me on occasion, but I don’t want to make an evening out of this.  Just not my preferred style.

500ml on tap at the Bavarian Bier Cafe, Parramatta. Pours a clear gold, with a sizeable, long-lasting head. Sweet on the nose, with some herbal notes appearing. Herbal and peppery hops to begin, with berry fruit in the middle and a whipped cream finish. Not the most complex beer out there, but an excellent easy drinker.

On tap on this side of the pond.  Pours a clear golden yellow with a small frothy white head.  Aroma is malty and grain.  Taste is clean, crisp with a small hop and grain snap at the end.  Very enjoyable helles.
Wow did not really enjoy this. Pale malts, faint hops, some light spicers. Did not really care for this and not worth going into much more detail.
20.11.2010. 0,5l Bottle. Pale yellow colour with white head. Refreshing beer with refreshing hops. Medium to thin body with very nice bitterness.
0,5 l bottle. Great golden color, rather small head. Sweetness from the malts is certainly the dominant feature. Quite balanced on the hops. Good basic lager!

500ml bottle. Pale gold with an inch of very white head. Light hay aroma with earth and spices. Taste is sweeter than suggested by the aroma with grainy malt and some nuts. Bitterness is enough to balance and pretty classy. A little metal as well as spices at the end. Balanced and pleasant but rather uneventful.

Poured a very light golden color.  Subtle aroma (slight malt/hop smell)/sort of skunky, Fizzy head disspated fairly quick.  Clear color.  Taste is a crisp, very light hop/malt flavor, slightly bitter.  Light body, thin texture, fizzy.   It is definitely drinkable, but nothing special; not much going on here.
Clean and crisp. Easy to drink. The aroma and taste is a nice balance of malt and hop though quite mild.

Aroma is of grainy, grassy hops (resulting from a good malt/hop balance).  Further sniffing reveals melanoidin (maltiness) perhaps the result of decoction, and all those nice toffee caramel flavors that come with it.  Flavor strikes a nice balance between grain, caramel, and bitterness, with minimal earthy hop flavor.  A hint of mineral/metalic notes, maybe raw grass/grain/vegetable.  Very drinkable, nicely balance.

Tap @ Konttori.

Pours a clear yellow colour with a thick, white and lacy head. Aroma of grainy malts with grass notes. Flavour of grainy malts, hay and grass with some honey notes. Light/medium bodied, slick mouthfeel.
bread, toast, golden, clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, salty, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter,
Transparent golden color in the glass. Light grainy malt aroma. Straightforward pilsner lager flavors, nothing too exotic, but a solid beer.

50cl bottle from Alko. Poured pale golden colour with a frothy white head. Aroma is slightly sweet and grainy malty. Flavor is slightly hoppy, semisweet and some spicy notes. Very clean, very drinkable. Could easily drink litres of this one.
Great german beer.  It’s a real easy drink and I liked the taste and aroma of it.  The palate isnt saturated.  Good overall, I recommend it if you like german beer, light golden, easy to drink brews.
Tap. Pale yellow with receding white head. Aromas of grass and grain. Flavors of malt and spice, pepper, citrus, pear. Hops add a lot. Thin body with smooth mouthfeel and moderate, soft carbonation.
0,5l bottle poured into a pint. Small white head. Light, golden colour. Quite ordinary. Some sweetness to it.

Very pale, golden colour. Rich white head. Slightly bready and grainy malt aroma with medium sweetish. Soft and grassy hoppiness with herbal undertones. Light bitterness. Smooth palate, medium body. Clean and pleasant, not spectacular.

On tap at Biermarkt: Golden colour with white frothy head.  Aromas of peppery hops, citrus, and grain.  Flavour is malty, hoppy, and bready.  Smoothly textured with a long btiter finish.  Above average.
Bottle. Clear golden with a medium white head. Quite hoppy aroma with notes of hay, caramel and malt. The flavour is hay, hops, some fruit and caramel. Nice and clean. Bitter hayish finish.

My wife wanted to know what this beer tasted like. I told her that it tasted like a Budweiser. Maybe a little better. Maybe a little worse.... Basically the same. Both of us then tasted the beer and blew it off. Boring look and feel. Next.

Tükrösen tiszta, világos aranysárga színű sör, termetes, hófehér és szivacsos habbal, ami lassan apad le. Illata mint a nedves istálló szalmáé egy kis komló virággal és malátával. Az első kortynál a maláta édeskés íze dominál, kis gyümölcsösséggel, aztán lassan bekúszik egy kevés komlós, virágos, kesernyés aroma is és ezek szépen kiegyensúlyozzák egymást. Nem túl testes, kissé de nem zavaróan vizes és közepesen buborékos. Utóízében is a maláta dominál és keserédesen, hosszan záródik. Nagyon könnyen iható, kellemesen frissítő, de nincs benne semmi különleges. Egyszerű, de kellemes ivósör.
A helles? Not really, more in the realm of inoffensive lagers, some sweet malt, bit of finishing bitterness, doesn’t travel well.

from old notes Pale gold hue accompanies a stark white froth.  Bright, malty aroma with melanoidins countered by peppery hops and a touch of sulfur.  Malt sugars develop into a bread sweetness and citric-peppery bite before a dry, grainy finish; lengthy satiating aftertaste.  Clean and light with fine carbonation and a silky texture.



Delicate and crisp, however the malts don’t translate well from the nose.



50 cl bottle, best before June 2009.
Not very pleasant. Pours like a flat budweiser; smells sweet; taste very sweet, almost cidery; not good
Nothing special, but not bad either. It has a hint of hops and grains with mild bitterness. A decent lighter lager.

Crystal clear golden with a small white head. The aroma is pleasant mix of bready pils malt and floral hops with a slightly spicy, citrusy note. The flavor has some light malt flavor, with some hops on the finish. Just enough bitterness to keep this a tad on the sweet side. Pretty tasty.

2010-07-04. Crisp yellow body with a small white head. 2+ Mild flavour, light bitterness, muted pale malt and light florals. Fewer unpleasant notes than the Pils sampled earlier. Mild aroma, lightly floral hops. Average to light palate. 2+ Meh, pretty dull but mostly inoffensive. On tap at Seattle International Beer Festival as Premium Lager
Labeled "Premium Lager" Somewhat standard, yet better than most light lagers, as its got some taste aspect to it without skunk. Not great but not bad

[3115-20100704] Sample. Not much aroma, a little grassy grains. Clear, pale yellow body with a quick foamy white head. Grainy grassy bread yeast flavour has a light aftertaste. Medium body. Pretty mainstream.

(Called "Premium Lager" @ SIB 2010, Seattle, WA)

Spaten Premium was one of the first beers I ever tasted.  Spaten is labeled as a malt liquor but I would not compare this to any of the typical cheap malts like mickeys or steal reserves most of us are used to.  In a league of its own you must try this beer to really understand it.
Pours very blonde yellow with a light head. Aroma is almost unnoticable with some malts, flavor is mostly malts. Like your average lager, except a bit lighter.

12 oz bottle:  Spaten Premium.  Aroma is rather mild clean, lightly grainy, very mild but not to funky hop scent,  Appearance is a clear golden with a medium sized head that linger around for quite a while.  Taste is clean, clear, slight grainy and corn notes, mild hop characteristic somewhat sweet, and some malt backing.  Palate is medium to high carbonation,  aftertaste has a lingering sweetness with a hop twang.  Overall, Better than I thought It would be.  Cheers!
Moderate grain aroma. Clear golden color with a small white head. Mild sweet beginning with a light yeast finish. Light palate.

Lucent gold, thin white head, medium body, medium co2. 



Aroma: musty, bready pale malt.



Taste: bready pale malt, vinous nobel hops.



Skunked green bottle, but i think it would very very nice if fresh and in good condition.

Golden color with a minimal head, much lighter than most would expect although it is a light lager. Decent taste, I thought it would taste like a dark beer but not bad at all for a light lager. There are much better German beers out there though. 8/20.

Had this as part of a taste test of the helles from all big 6 Munich breweries.  A bit sweeter than the other six.  I think I liked this more than everyone else.  Not the best helles but I’m happy enough it.  Serving: Bottle and tap

A ight grainy malt aroma. Clear yellow. Subtle malt taste with a clean bitterfinish. A clean refreshing beer. A great lawn mower beer if you want something with more character than a light corn lager.

Versa un colore giallo molto chiaro,limpidissimo,schiuma abbondante e frizzante di media persistenza.Aroma gradevole con lievi note maltate.Sapore cerealoso ed erbaceo,buono l’amaro.Una birra senza pretese di grandezza ma comunque piacevole da bere in una giornata calda.
Pours a clear yellow body with next to no head. Primarily sweet, some corn and hay. Malts throughout.

Bottle.  At first whiff, I immediately thought skunk.  The aroma is dominated by skunk.  The taste is clean and crisp with hints of skunk.  Appearance is pale with light carbonation.  Palate is very clean.  This beer was better for cooking sausage than drinking to be honest.
5-liter keg purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $15.99 Not a bad daily beer.
Pours a clear gold with a white head.  Aroma is skunky and the taste is sweet.   Very thin with lots of carbonation.  Easy to drink.
Nice gold pour with decent sized head. Nose and taste is sweet, peppery and a little musty grape. Rated 1/15/2000
Bottle. Clear yellow color with a white head. Aroma: Malty with some herbal hops. Flavor: Malty, sweet, bread, herbal hops, light bitterness. Smooth and easy drinking.

Draft at Mecklenburg Gardens in Cincinnati.  Pours a mostly clear yellow gold color with a finger-thick white head.  Aroma of straw, grass, corn, grains, pale malts, dry hops, and dust.  The flavor follows suit pretty well, grainy and corny, with plenty of grass and straw and some honey sweetness.  Dry all the way through.  Light-bodied, with a good amount of carbonation and a fizzy mouthfeel.  Light, sessionable, decent.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma with cardboard, some flower essences, herbal hops notes and hay-ish notes. Sweetish flavor, slightly bready, with a bit of rubbery notes and a finish with some hop bitterness. Light-bodied. A bit weird, probably past its prime.
Golden with white head - solid malt body with nice hop bitterness that continues into thr finish - good beer
Bottle.  Optimator: Good.  Premium: Not good.  Tastes like heineken or something.  Light and metallic with a bit of sweet hay.  Bleh.
Deep golden color.  Light, quickly dissipating head.  The nose is light and clean.  Nice bright, crisp mouthfeel.  This beer is quite refreshing with no unpleasant aftertaste.  Very sessionable.

At a tasting, thanks zvikar, small head that dissapears quite quickly, quite clear pale yellow colour, aroma of cardboard and flowey soap with a hint of bready malt, light sweetness  and a rubbery sensation, a little coarse bitter aftertase. Maybe a little over the hill.

Pours light golden yellow with a bright white head. Bubbles like champagne. Head thins out, but hangs around to nearly the end with some light lacing. Smelled quite skunky! I couldn’t smell much over it. Damn Green Bottles! Tastes kinda skunky too, but not so bad. Taste is a little thinner than I had hoped. Nicely balanced though. Crisp and light and a little sweet on the finish. Reminds me of a Stella or a Heine. Similar style and quality to me. Easy to drink.

@ a Tasting, thanks Ohandos, pours yellow bubbly with a medium head, aroma of clove, coriander, leather, wheat and vinous acidity, very light flavor with some honey biscuit and coriander, some bizarre flavor in the aftertaste, light to medium body.

Spaten Premium--2000 12 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Green bottle.  Very clear light yellow color.  Medium light Saaz front.  Clean crisply flavored body.  Nice head and lace.  Flavorful rich lightly sweet body with mild Bavarian twist.  Mild buttery clean hop end.  Sampled 8/13/2000.
Clear golden pour white head skunky malt aroma light lacing ..... taste of sweet malts and straw ..... smooth and easy drinking with a light bitter finish .... a sessionable and average german brew

Bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a rather pale gold with a disappearing froth of white fizz. Aroma is earthy and grainy with a hint of caramel and some mustiness. Definitely a bit more to this than the appearance would indicate. Soft malty flavor, mostly grainy, some light breadiness, mild grassiness. I’m liking the lack of a strong metallic character which a lot of German lagers have. This is very crisp and finishes dry. One of the better pale lagers around.
On tap at The Taphouse, pours a pale yellow. Aroma of bread, herbs and grassy hops. Flavour is off-putting - hay, bread and some distasteful spices/herbs. Not good.

Personnally I am not a big fan of Dortmunders, but this one is okay.  Pours a very pale yellow, almost clear.  It is much cleaner than most Dortmunders, sweet with a touch of bitterness.  High carbonation bubbles in the mouth.  Overall not bad, but not my tea.

Bottled, clear yellow with bright white head, grassy hops with slight papery aroma and light bready malt character, crisp clean flavor with light malt and grassy hops noted, full bodied palate with appropriate level of carbonation for flavor/style wihout being too watery

Crystal clear golden yellow with a short-lived bright white head and lacing. Barnyard graininess with a touch of lemon on the nose. Slight skunk. Mild biscuity malts and a hint of bitterness on the tongue. Light body, generous carbonation, and a dryish hops note in the aftertaste.

12oz bottle. Pours a normal golden lager color with lots of carbonation and a bubbly, short lived head. Smells like hay. Tastes of hay with a metallic undertone. Not too offensive. Quite refreshing. Not the worst by any means.
Draught (at Bavarian Bier Cafe in Manly, Sydney). A clear gold with a large white head. A herbal hop nose. Creamy mouthfeel, some citrus hop with a clean finish.
Mini-keg.  Yellow-gold, thin white head.  Corn, grainy cereal, malty and a touch of grass.  Surprsingly sweet, a little too sweet, but otherwise drinkable and decent enough.  No skunk.
Clear straw color, little bits of soapy white head. Grainy slightly skunky aroma. Lightly grainy taste, clean finish. Mild overall.
Bottle. Clear gold, white carbonation. Fresh grains, corn, cereal grains, mild malt sweetness, moderate dose of earthy and bitter hops. Light body, easy, finishes a touch dry. Decent lager.

0,5L bottle.
Clean yellow lager with fluffy white head. Husky cereal and white bread malt aromas combine with light perfumed notes of hop on the nose. The body is quite crisp, reveal a honey-like malt sweetness and herbal hop character. Carbonation is restrained for the style and bitterness is moderate; seemling just enough to give balance to this beer.
A bit of skunked yeast flavour lingers on the finish, but this is a reasonably good helles overall.

On tap. Pours a very clean light golden with a very thick creamy white head. ASubdued aromas of grassy hops, a little malt sweetness and perhaps a little sherbet. Flavours show plenty of malt sweetness and restrained grassy hops. Not usually my style but a nice clean beer.

Pale yellow pour form a 12 oz bottle. One finger of thin white head that thins down to just a trace, but then persists, fed by active and fine bubbled carbonation. Faint aroma of light grassy hops. Flavor is very light malt with a dry, slightly hoppy finish. Palate is fueled by the actve and refined carbonation. Nothing bad here but a bit of a disappointment in the lack of character and zest.
Pale yellow with a small white head. Clean aroma of straw and herbal hops. Dry and malty flavour, herbal hops and medium bitterness. Just a hint of sulphur
Golden straw colour, fluffy white head. Light malt aroma with clean spicy hop aroma. Palate is clean & refreshing with light malt flavour.

Pours beautiful golden color and crisp/clear. Pure whiteness on the head. beauty.

Nose is fairly faint but has a straw with ’german skunk’ aroma (you know, from green bottles... Beck’s is the worst)

Palate is simply clean, dry, crisp, and overall fairly refreshing. I’m sure this would quench a hard earned thirst after lawn mowing duties on a summer afternoon.

Finish has a touch of malt sweetness.

Refrigerated bottle served in a glass.  Pours a clear pale yellow with little white head.  Light maltyness, pretty nice balance between crisp hops and floral malt with a hint of skunk (get some brown bottles).  Nicely carbonated and some lacing.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a crystal clear, yellow-gold body with a finger-width, foamy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is fruity, lightly sweetened pale malts and some grass. Flavor is sweeter pale malts and fruits with a light grass and a bit of a toast in the finish. Dry with an ever so light cloying sweetness and a moderate aftertaste. Light bodied, crisp, and refreshing. Overall, better than I anticipated and somewhat flavorful for a lighter lager.

Pours estremely pale with frothy, white head.  Good lacing.  Extremely clear with champagne-like carbonation.  Spicy, floral hop aroma with light malt character.  Moderately hoppy flavor with a slightly dry finish.  Fairly well balanced.  A little bit of skunk.  Crisp and clean.
Light golden color and nice carbonation a little sour aftertaste that makes it crisp and drinkable but nothing particularly amazing.

Botle, 2009-05-15, Göteborg
AP: cowslip (the flower) yellow, creamy high head, wee fine curtains
AR: a hint of light bread
F: malty, and a hint of vanilla
AF: Long and lasting

Poured from bottle into Summit glass.

Bright, clear and rich gold with fluffy white head. No lacing but quite pretty.

Aroma of apples, lemon, hay and maybe a touch of noble hops.

Dry malts with an emphasis on apple, grass and hay. Slight spiciness appears at the finish to help balance the beer slightly, but this is mostly about the malts.

Moderately high carbonation, light to medium body. I would say it has a dry finish but there is a grainy aftertaste that unfortunately gets in the way.

Great German lager for a hot day or as a simple accompaniment to food or friends.
Sample at Esbjerg Beerfestival. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are rich malty, hops and notes of citrus. Semi oily.

(Draught at Flying Scotsman, Stockholm) Golden colour with frothy, white head. Malty, bready nose with grass, butter and some citrus. Malty taste with notes of bread, hay, grass, hints of tropical fruit, some butter and grassy hops in the finish. Medium body with some malt sweetness throughout. Decent lager, but hardly exciting.
Pours very yellowy with a  thin white head.  Tastes very dry, kinda wheaty, very light on the hops.  Overall, goes down pretty smooth, nothing too wrong with it.
12 oz bottle. Pours pale yellow with a very thin white ring of bubbles. Aroma is earthy, hay with a slight sweetness. Taste is lightly sweet malt, with hay, wet grain, and light hops.
&#40bottle 50cl called Spaten Munich&#41  Pours golden with a thin white head. Aroma of malt and hay. Malty flavour fresh and light body,
A nice light lager with delicate hop flavors and moderate bitterness. Not much else to it, a simple beer but quite satisfying.

120z bottle.  Poured a clear bright golden color with a nice fluffy white head.  Has a very faint aroma of hops and lemon zest.  Has a light crisp taste of bitter grainy hops that finishes with a touch of sweet biscuity malt.  Very thin and light.
From a mixed pack from Central Market Fort Worth.  Clear yellow pour with a brief head.  Weak taste.
Bitter, and like others have stated has a smell like that of a fresh cut lawn... not something I prefer in my beer, and actually tastes like it has grass clippings in it.

12oz bottle.  I’m happy with my progression as a rater, I correctly identified this beer as being a Helles without previously knowing.  Unfortunately, Spaten is known for being very crisp and clean tasting and this isn’t their finest example of that.  Pours a lighter clear straw color with tiny bubbles and medium fine froth on top.  Aroma is light, a balance of sweet munich malt, breadiness and grass.  Flavor follows, really balanced, nothing really stands out, some brediness, grass, sweet munich, longer grassy doughy aftertaste.  Medium/light bodied, classic Spaten, super smooth great carbonation, but not quite as crisp.  A passable Helles, not Spaten’s best, but I can see the wider appeal.
500 ml on tap in the USA, It is a good solid Helles but not a great one. Not bad for a German Macro. I thiink my higher rating is due to the fact I got this one on tap.
Bottle.  Clear golden pour with a small white head.  Aroma is faint, typical european hop scent. Flavor is typical european lager, nothing very good about this one.

I don’t like the Spaten Oktoberfest and the Spaten Optimator. They aren’t horrible, just mediocre by the best standards. It was with great trepidation that I tried their Premium, a German Macro Lager which I feared would flow like bottled water and taste just about the same. Of course, at times that comparison does a disservice to the delicious refreshment of ice-cold water, but I digress. As I was to quickly find out, the Spaten Premium Lager was a pleasant exception.




She poured a clear gold straw color with a bleached white head which fades slowly into splotchy patches of bubbly foam. As her head recedes, I am touched by a gentle showing of lace; not overpowering, but a subtle indication that I could be in for a pleasant surprise. Her nose is rich with grains, hay, and a dab of fresh honey. A bit of a delicate nose, there is thankfully no cloying corny sweetness, just a nice blanket of fresh grains and white breads touched by honey and lemon blossoms. My first quaff is bright and spritzy with tight carbonation. In a complete turn-around from her nose, honey arrives first and finds her seat while white bread, grains, and lemon meander on in, lazing around before settling in for the rest of the showing. Her honey is gently mouth-coating while lemon dances on top of my tongue. The white breads and fresh grains make up the meat of her palate, and the only thing I have left to do is happily quaff the rest of my glass.




I have no problem being absolutely wrong about a beer, especially when it is a positive reversal of fortunes as is the case with the Spaten Premium Lager. I still don’t like their other beers, but the lager gets a solid nod of approval from me. She fought hard and stood tall in the face of macro conformity, green bottles, and importation to come out victorious.

Transparent gold, white head gone quick but nice legs. Nose of incredibly robust grain, some grass and faint hop. Odd, plain flavor, some dirty grain and minor hop but rather watery. Palate is somewhat crisp, finish almost nonexistent but some dirty grain remains. Pretty standard, but still rather enjoyable.

Pint on tap. Pours straw gold with frothy white head that settles to a rim around the glass. Aroma of grain, quite weak. Flavour was weird, quite wheaty and grainy, some hefe esque banana, with a dishwater sort of feel. Finish was corn, with mild bitterness. Not offensive, but very overrated, Hofbrau blows this out of the water.

Some sort of mug like draft served on tap at Poag Mahone’s (Chicago, IL). Pours a clear golden hue, bubbly white decent head with small lacing. Aromas are straight grain and corn, a bit of funkiness, but overall not offensive, just a touch adjuncty. Initial is sweet cereal malts, corn, adjunct, a bit boozy a bit sugary sweetness. Finish is sharp corny sweetness and light bitterness. The sweetness almost makes me puke, balance is WAY off and near unbearable for a session beer as the booze fades away. This beer does not do beer justice, over sweetened for booze. Dissappointing.
Bottle.  Pours a golden body with a white head.  Dry earth y spicy with some dry earth y tones.  Grain y sweet with a lighter paper dried fruit note. Eh.

Presentation: It was poured from a green 12oz bottle into a Pilsener glass. There appears to be no freshness date and the label reads "malt liquor".

Appearance: It has a light golden colored body with very good clarity and some visible streams of carbonation. The head on top is light and foamy, bright white in color and fades out quickly.

Smell: The aroma is very light with just a hint of pale malt and grassy/floral hop notes.

Taste/Mouth Feel: The flavor is simple crisp and refreshing with a light to medium body. There is a thin biscuity malt balanced by floral and somewhat grassy hops that bring mild but balanced bitterness. The finish is quick and fairly dry with active cleansing carbonation.

Notes: It has an easy drinking texture and a good simple and balanced flavor.

Yelow corn colored pour, leaving 1/2 finger of white head.  Aroma is skunky with hint of grains.  The taste is thin, bitter skunk at the front, some corn/ grains in the middle with mild bitters remaining.

Overall Impression: 
A clear golden beer with a decent, but not overwhelming or outstanding taste to it.
Clear golden color with a bright white head. Grassy hop aroma, hay, grainy. Not much flavor. Mostly grainy with a touch of hops. Thin palate, really thin and watery.

Bottle. Light aromas of straw for the malt, grass for the hops and hints of wine, steamed vegetables like celery, and band aid. Head is small, fizzy, white with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is sparkling super-clear gold. Flavor starts lightly acidic and bitter, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Plalate is light, watery, has a lively carbonation and finishes lightly alcholic and dry. This is not my favorite version of a Dortmunder.

Had onboard the Sapphire Princess (no plug intended!).  Poured a medium clear gold beneath a smallish white head.  Aroma was quite hopped, and the taste was rather bitter - no complaints here.  Mouthfeel was thinner than I like.

500 ml bottle, at a pub in the Nordstan shopping centre, Göteborg, as "Spaten München - Original Munich beer". ABV is 5.2%. Pale golden colour, moderate head. Pleasant aroma of flowery hops. The flavour is fairly bland and boring, but there are no unpleasant off-flavours.

No: 743

Rated: 27.06.2009

Bottle brown, 500 ml,11.7 P. got it in Munchen

Appearance: Pours pale metalic, shiny yellow, not perfectly clear in the body texture, carbonation of the body is very weak, head is just white, foamy, initially medium, quickly decreasing to almost non existant, no lacing, pretty dull looking body, gently citrusy in colour, gentle sediments are floating in the body texture.

Aroma: Rather weak, weaker than Helles beer from Lowenbrau Brauerei, notes of dust and very gentle flowery - spicy hoppyness mixed with alcoholic background. Quite typical aroma of Helles beer but rather weak what is present in its weak malty - crispy background despite its 11.7 P, tea like impression (of a regular black, non-sophisticated tea).

Flavour: Front is slaty oriented with watery oily mouthfeel, notes of alcoholic warmth go together with spicy notes of hops origin, rather non-sophisticated and water aftertaste with no crispness of malt origin, poor flowery side of hops, somehow lacking in this interpretation of Helles style. Finish duration is short, beer is not that clean in the aftertaste as Hellers beer from Lowenbrau Brauerei.

Palate: Body is light, texture is watery, carbonation on palate is moderate, finish feel is slightly accidic and moderately astringent, slightly alcoholic and kin of dull.

Have had this dozens of times, usually from old skunky bottles at get-togethers, this time from a newish green bottle served in a dimpled half-liter from Löwenbräu (Forgive my blasphemy!).  Extremely grassy, outdoorsy nose overspills the bottle, malt with decent backing from noble hops.  Unfortunately, some notes somewhere between mashy grain and corn.  Pale (clear) golden pour with a frothy white head.  Malty sweet taste with above mentioned grass and near-corn, now with a little citrus in the main and a mildly bready finish.  Manages a nice, rounded balance, soft water does wonders for an otherwise bland medium body.  Light bitterness and spice; endlessly repeatable Helles-Pilsner hybrid and, when fresh, great beer for the warm and inviting outdoors. [2009.06.30: 3.2]  

Sixer of green-glassed bottles marked 03.2020, from WineWorks in Marlton.  Really nailed my initial review, perhaps only underplaying a subtle but persistent spiciness.  Killer when fresh.  [2019.09.02: 3.4]

Pours pale yellow with a 1-2 finger foamy white head that has good retention. Aroma is grass, fresh grain, a little hay and light planty notes. Flavor is sweet hay, grass, lightly toasted grain and a little honey to the finish. Palate is thin, with a neutral feel and a light, fizzy carbonation.
Pours a large white head of foam. Pale  yellow appearence. You can smell the barley in the aroma. The taste not to overpowering and does not leave an aftertaste.

Drank tons of this stuff back in high school and was pleased to enjoy some again furing a backyard cook out. A gold colored and slightly hoppy tasteing helles. Yes it is a bit watery but just enough carbination for what i needed it for

Split with curly at woody’s.  Pours a very clear very pale yellow with small ring of white head.  Corn, skunk, grass nose.  Same flavor.  It is great for a skunky green bottle beer.  If that’s what you’re in the mood for.

Draught at Bavarian Bier Cafe, Manly. Pretty horrid stuff after you’ve been drinking a few better beers on the day. I had this while waiting for a ferry back to the city. It wasn’t bad for cleaning the palate but i struggled to finish the glass (and the reason being a very over priced beer so I wasn’t gonna waste any)! Perhaps it tastes better in the homeland but I doubt it.
On tap at the Beechtree.  Pours a light hazy yellow with a thin white head.  Smells mostly of grain, with a hint of plum.  Thin body, grainy.  Finishes dry and with even more grain.  Not so tasty.
Bottle 50 CL, as München. Apperance; Yello, clear with a small white head. A sweet, malty, butter/oil aroma. A malty flavor with a light bitter ending.

Golden in color. A faint aroma of malt.  A taste of sweet malt. Also has a sweet finish.
Quite easy to drink.
Bottle. Clear, golden, not much head. Little aroma, tastes slightly spicy with a sweet corn flavour. Feels a bit foamy in the mouth.

500ml bottle. A clear pale yellow beer with a  large white head. Unremarkable nose of grainy malt sweetness with a tiny amount of floral hops. The taste is mainly sweet malt with quite a sweet finish and a touch of metal at the end which rather lets it down. Medium-light bodied with easy-going mouthfeel. Refreshing and sessionable but nothing to write home about.

This is a great tasting beer. My first time drinking it was this weekend and I’ll put it in my top 5 beers. A golden, hint of sweetness but not overpowering, smooth tasting, crisp beer. A good summer quencher.
one of my top ten; very light and clear, this beer pours well and leaves a decent head. unique aroma (somewhat citrusey) with a mild hops flavor and a hint of lemon. very well balanced beer.

50cl bottle. as spaten munchen original munich beer.
clear yellow, thick creamy, almost oily wihte head. very faint aroma that is slightly citrussy and slightly sweet.
flavor is slightly hoppy, slighlty sweet,  easy-drinker , refreshing. alc. well proportinoed to taste. it’s nothing special really, but quite tasty.

Pours with a dark gold hue with a non-existing head. Aroma is of grain, urine, with lots of yeast and bread. 
Flavor has a yeasty beginning with a slightly sweet and hoppy ending. The Yeastiness of the beer in the beginning overshadows the hoppy finish in my opinion. 
Light mouthfeel with light carbonation.

Pours a pale gold color, with a small off white head.  Smells of crisp grain, really mild hops, and cinnamon malt.  Nothing special here.  The taste was more malt than anything with traces of grain and corn.  Really didnt have that great of flavor.  a bit of cinnamon sweetness was left in the finish, but really not that great drinking.  Id need to drink it ice cold while mowing my lawn.

This beer is our speciality. In 1894 Spaten became the first brewery in Munich to produce this brand of light lager. Golden in color with a well-balanced hop-flavor. The full rounded body is a superb balance between hops and a malty sweetness.
On tap. Aroma is slightly grassy. Light gold in color with a small white head. Flavor is well balanced with sweet malt and mildly bitter hops. Crisp and bubbly, a very easy drinking beer.
I don’t know...this beer didn’t do much for me, it just kind of existed. Tell your friends
Pours clear gold with a disappearing white head. Skunky hop aroma and a slight bitter skunk taste. This beer is pretty average for a green bottle.
A 12oz bottle. The beer pours a light gold with a thin head. The smell faint hops. The taste is light hops and a hint of malt. It is easy to drink.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thin head of poor duration, over a clear pale yellow body....nose is mild malts, mild hoops, smells like a light type of beer....taste initially a mild maltyness, then mild hopping finishing with clean dry malt...mouthfeel is light. Meets its type very well. The style is very light to my palate and my rating reflects that.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Slightly hazy, golden yellow color with a tall layer of fizzy white foam.  A slightly skunky hop aroma wafts from the glass immediately after pouring, but fades after a few seconds, unveiling a soft malty nose of bready pils malt.  Rich and clean with a soft doughy sweetness.  Hops are restrained, but lend an herbal and mildly spicy character.  Medium bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a soft, doughy texture.  Clean pils malt flavor that’s pleasantly doughy and bready.  The soft mouthfeel enhances the maltiness of the beer nicely and the subtlety of the pils malt flavor stands out with restrained aggression.  A mild herbal hop bitterness rounds out the finish.  A nice, light, and clean session beer with a pleasing pils malt flavor.

[bottle]
Sort of pungent grassy aroma, foretelling of crisp malt, with creamy notes. Clear, coppery gold with a lasting white cover. that laces the glass walls. Clean base malt flavour with a tiny bit of bittering, which is only stabilizing. Nice, quaffable, refreshing Helles. Light body, medium carbonation, crisp and clean finish. Just not really exciting.

I have to go against the ratings here, I had this on tap in Tokyo recently and I was in heaven. Gold with rocky white head, the carbonation was so soft and busy, beautiful to look at. Nose was spicy with grains and sweet yeasts. The taste was mostly sweet with hints of lemon and citrus. The palate was incredibly soft and so effervescent - it was like a foamy cream. I loved this beer, loved it.

Pours and attractive gold with a small white head. Typical for any lager. Aroma/flavour of mild hops and malts with some hints of spice. Also tiny notes of corn and wheat. A tad sweet also. Great lager. I wish they supplied it where I live......like so many other beers.

What can I say..... I generally like Spaten enough not to even mind their InBev ownership; generally I turn the other way and enjoy their quality above all. To this however there was very little turning, this was particularly not so great.  Pours a very clear light golden color, as you can see from the picture. The aromas were of apple bread dough yeast and malty sweetness. The flavor was bready with a sharp hoppiness and a pronounced character of corn, which I am absolutely certain, had nothing to do with adjunct grain. It is unfortunate to find a corn character when you are sure that there is no corn in the beer. Otherwise the flavor is largely dry and can be enjoyable in small quantities, at the right occasion.

A well-crafted example of a not too interesting style in my opinion.  Golden color with a white head.  Aroma is sweet malt, German hops, and some grain.  Flavor is pale malt with mild hops, a little grainy but not bad.  Medium mouthfeel, crisp on the finish.
Pours a beautiful golden color with a very nice rocky white head. Aroma is classic German, spicy hop and Munich maltiness. Flavor is crisp, refreshing with a dry refreshing finish.

A- Pours a very clear, light yellow hue; minimal head with no lacing

S- Suble Bavarian malts and hops; slight citrus and grain/corn tones

T- Refreshing and crisp maltiness followed by subtle bitterness; I get a strong corn flavor in the finish

M- Very thin and watery, light carbonation

D- Smooth, refreshing lager; alcohol taste is very unassuming; this would be a nice beer to drink on a summer day; I get the feeling that I could have quite a few servings without being overwhelmed

Bottle. Pours a brilliant golden yellow with a nice white head. The is THE color of beer. Spaten is what Budweiser wishes it could be but never will. I must have gotten a hold of a perfect six. No skunk, crisp, refershing, great balance, nice aftertaste. When you talk about drinkabliity, Spaten is the beer your should be talking about.

12 oz bottle. Light spicy hop aroma with some Munich style maltiness. Wow...this botttle is not skunked at all. Clear light straw golden with big bubbles. Light maltiness with some a very light spicy hop flavor. Finish is clean and dry.

12 oz. bottle - $1.49 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a clear, yellow body with a foamy, white head.

Smell: Lightly skunky nose with notes of spicy, floral hops, pale malts, and the tiniest bit of apple fruitiness.

Taste: Light pale malts with a pinch of sugary sweetness followed by flowery, spicy hops with a mild, restrained bitterness. Very minor hint of Golden Delicious apples. Finishes dry and crisp.

Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: Aside from the souring skunkiness, it’s a fine, enjoyable lager.
Pale yellow with a nice soft fuzz of white cover.  Grainy tannic malt, peppery spices.  Taste is fair, pepper and malt, bitter grain husks.

Bottle at The Headkeeper, Greensburg, PA. Pours a golden yellow, small white head. Aroma is hops, malt and maybe a touch of corn. Flavor profile is more of the same only it has a touch sweetness to it that isn’t there in the aroma, also a little bready.
Bottle: Poured a golden with white head. Aroma was very little. Taste was corn.

Gold in colour with piss weak thin white head. A light coloured lager basically. Little malt and hops and quite refreshing. Not my thing though and I would always pick something else before I have this again.

Pours a clear bright golden with a rather minimal frothy white head.  Grain and spice aroma.  Taste is sweet malt and, I know there isn’t any in German beer, corn grits along with a very slight bitterness.  I must have a fresher bottle than many other raters because there is no skunk aroma or taste in this sample.  Nevertheless, there isn’t much going on here.  Quite refreshing but unremarkable.

Bottle, 12 oz

Pale yellow, large white head.  Nose is slightly skunked, with a little honey and floral hops.  Taste is slightly skunked and a little tart, with some grain flavors and a metallic aftertaste.  Carbonation is high.  Mouthfeel is very light. Overall, disappointing but refreshing.
Straw color with a small white head.  Very carbonated.  The minute you open the bottle you can smell the skunk.  Crisp clean beer with a nice finish.  Good stuff

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear golden straw color with an average size fluffy white head and lots of visible carbonation. Aroma of skunk, some mustiness and cereal grains lying underneath. Cereal grain flavors with a touch of honey sweetness and a metalic finish. Classic German lager that those not in the know swear is awesome beer.

golden pour. dissipating pour,
fresh, lemony, slightly hoppy
sweet, slight herbal hops,
good brew
Golden. Fast head. Aroma of grain malts, somewhat skunked. Flavor of grain malts end with hop bite. Lite bitter finish.  Why German brewers want to ship green bottles across the pond, no idea.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of Lumpy)  Pours a clear golden body with a small white quickly diminishing head.  Aroma of skunkiness, metallic, grass, lemon zest, and mustiness.  Flavor of grassy hops and metallic.
Light gold with a small white head. Aroma is slightly fruity. Sweet, very little bitterness.
Bottle. A light beer, kind of summer-like. Probably something you would like to drink outside a hot summer-day.
Bottle, 5.2%. OK malty aroma. Clear golden colour. Very small white head. The flavour is mild, malty, slightly sweet. Low bitterness.
Bottle from Carringtons.  Dull as dishwater with only slightly more flavour and a better colour.  Nothing to see here, kindly move on.
It’s just an average german beer with a sort of skunky kind of smell to it and a crisp taste. Nothing too great.
Mini-keg.  Foamy head.  Pale golden color.  Not bad.  Had a malty flavor, and a slight fruitiness to it.  Thicker than I expected.

500ml bottle from the Supermarket. This is a very pale lager. Rather watery with cow dung and chemical flavours. Some butter. It’s drinkable, and there’s a bit of interest as it flows over the tongue, but the interest has nothing to do with experiencing aesthetically pleasing tastes.

12oz bottle.  clear yellow pour with thin white head.  aroma of honey and hay.  clean crisp biscuity malt taste.  bit of lemon to it.  medium body.  drinkable.  feel like this would pair well with a brat.  but could just be that I’m hungry right now.
I’m not usually a fan of this type of beer, but this is one of the best
A 0.5L bottle from Alko shop. White fast dissapearing head. Clear pale hey coloured. A grassy nose. Mild slightly sweet fruity and sour taste with mild hoppiness.

Pours a medium straw color into a pint glass.  With a small head that becomes a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is grassy and slightly hoppy.  Taste is slightly malty sweet up front and slightly hoppy as it finishes.  Overall a decent, drinkable brew.

From a 2oz sample X 85. aka a mini-keg. Well, I’ll see if I can finish it. Aroma: not so great, smells like a lot of a bit more than average premium lager. Taste: Quite good, rather nutty. Finishes pretty dry. The finish is excellent. Very easy drinking and thirst quenching.

O gosto não me agradou a princípio mas é uma cerveja interessante de se beber. Preciso tomar ela antes das outras durante uma prova.

A cor me agradou também.
Golden sparkle, nice thin head on top.  I really liked this beer, simple yet refined.  I could drink this casually all day long.  Will buy again for sure.
0.5 l bottle. Deep golden color. The aroma and flavor is sweetish, firmly malty and honeyish aroma with traces of herbal hops. Good everyday beer, well made helles.

500ml bottle. Small white foamy head. Goes away fast. Small bubbles tickles the head of the tongue nicely. g. Cristal clear yellow colour. Aroma has hops and peach. Flavor is hoppy and dry with hints of bread. Refreshing, easy going.
Nice aroma and solid beer all around. Probaby one of the better drinkable beers I have had in the Lager family.
Bottle.  Yellow pour wtih a big white head.  Aroma of malt, cracker, and some earthy tones as well.  Flavor is malty and pretty damn boring.  Some hops finish this one ok...zzzzzzzzz.

Bottle.  Poured a crystal clear, pale yellow color with a thick, frothy white head.  Aroma of pilsner malt, some soft biscuit, a bit of honey, and some light grassy hops.  Smooth entry with some lightly sweet, biscuity malts and a very light fruitiness lead into a grassy hoppiness with some light homey undertones.  Smooth on the palate, but a bit thin.  Not a bad beer at all, especially compared to much more popular beers like Heineken.

Poured from bottle a golden with medium sized white head.  Aroma is toasted malt.  Flavor is malt, lightly toasted sweet bread, and a little cardboard but not too bad.  This one has a malty-high carbonation mouth feel ending mildly bitter with a little astinency.  Overall, an easy to drink beer with some ok flavors and a few off ones but much better than most american macros.  I’d drink again on occasions.
Golden yellow pour releases a neutral but delightful aroma, light, crisp, and sweet, decent beer.
Just a very light lager to me. Feels light on the palate, light in flavor and alcohol. Not too much to say of this one. No hops detected.
(Bottle).  Malty aroma.  Clear pale golden color, average head.  Mild flavor, not much going on.  A bit of yeast and malt.

Decent frothy head on gold pour,ample carbonation,corn liker aroma,hoppy fresh,malt even.Flavouris corn touch,hoppy,nice bitter,hops are well done.Bitter has a lasting effect in taste,at the finish.Some good beers from the Munich region ,this is another.

Bottle bought at the Utah State Store. Pours a clear golden body with a thick white head. The aroma is full of malt, grass and some apples. The flavor is very smooth and nice; a nice fruity body, some rich and sweet malts, and a spicy peppery finish. Very clean and watery. Not bad at all. The German lager often exceeds my expectations, and this was no exception. Too thin, but good.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a golden color with a light white head.  A yeast aroma becomes apparent.  Taste of malts and maybe some grass and caramel flavors.  LIght bodied.  Finishes crisp with mild bitterness.  Slightly better than a standard American macro.

Pours blonde from the bottle with a trim head of white foam.  Plenty of carbonation with a yeasty/citrus aroma.  Very light with a faint taste of grass and malt.  Better than most macro lagers, yet still lacking in the flavor department.

Sparkling, rich yellow pour with a foamy, white head. Strong carbonation and solid lacing round out a very nice appearance. Peppery, grainy malt scent, lots of fresh grass and subtle noble hops. Light and soft on the palate. Gentle, creamy finish with a mildly bitter aftertaste. Flavor is in tune with the style. Great balance of spicy, green hops and pale, grassy malts. Quenching and very drinkable, a lager to be thrown back in good fashion.
Pours gold into a stein.  Bright white head quickly recedes to hug rim leaving no lacing. Skunky malt aromas. Full and crisp.  Sweet upfront with a dry hop finish.

Light gold/yellow.White head.The aroma is of hay,straw, maybe a hint of citrus.Sweet flavor with some faint bitterness.Smooth texture.Lingering slightly bitter finish.Light body.Pleasant,very drinkable.It gets sweeter as you go.Good.

Tasted somewhere along my trip through the States.

Pale golden colored brew. Crispy and grainy. Not bad, but not special.
Bright, clear yellow with decent white head. Not particularly bubbly/carbonated. Pleasantly hoppy with a nice mouthfeel, but not a distinctive flavor.

This is a fine beer but I dont get the hype. German beer this Belgian beer that. This is a typical lager done perfectly. You can describe this as classical but im standby TYPICAL. American Micro’s blow this out of the water with innovation, imo.
Bottle pours a very clear, medium yellow with an average sized head.  Aroma is slightly sweet and malty.  Flavor is light, crisp, and refreshing.  Not bad at all.
pours very light yellow, with medium white head, no lacing at all, taste is quite simple and bland. smell is kind of skunky not very impressive!

50cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. It poured a very pale yellow colour with a medium head that settled down fast in the glass. The aroma smells of malts. The flavour is is watered out and tastes of bread. It has almost no aftertaste at all.
This reminds me of a Heineken but kicked up a notch. A little skunky and metallic in taste but does have slight notes of hops and some but barely malt. Not to bad overall I suppose.
Bottle. Pours pale yellow with a white head. Sweet, hoppy, cereal aroma with notes of bread. Flavour is sweet cereals and hops. A bit metallic. Bread-like finish with faint apple notes. 28-07-08.
Had on tap just outside of Munich.  Had a nice light appearance with a crisp flavor with a hint of hops.  Nice beer on a warm day spent walking all over Deutchland.

Straw coloured with a decent head. Aroma sweeter than I expected (but then I was drinking it under the impression of it being a pils) and a bit grainy or even dusty. Nice mouthfeel but flavour is more sweet than grassy and hops could be stronger. Again, I thought I was tasting a pils. It’s a decent beer either way but more impressive to me as a helles than a pils.

Draft.  I really enjoyed it - a nice, traditional German lager.  It has the smoothness there, wonderful hop and grain crispness, with slight floral notes to keep things interesting.  Probably my favorite macro-brewed helles.

Draft.  Very solid traditional helles.  It has a nice balance of sweet maltiness, balanced by just a touch of hoppy bite.  Very well balanced, refreshing when cold, substantial when a bit warmer.  Very pleased.

I like this beer a lot!  it delivers what it should for the style.  Even and well-rounded malt body.  Hop flavor is even and compliments malt perfectly.  Some citrus and banana notes in the afteraste...overall a great beer!

On tap. Helles??? Tasted like a big bunch of nothing. Aroma had some vague sweet malt, in the mouth some grassy hops as well, but very, very bland. Finished like a cheap pale lager, nothing that made me particularly want to finish the glass. Blah. I don’t usually rate beers around 2.0, so I’m not sure if I’m being generous or overly critical, but blah about sums it up.
On draft at the Saucer.  Has a light golden body with faint head.  Aroma is of sweet Pils malt with some herbal hop notes.  Taste is similar, but a bit sweet.  Decent German lager.

On tap.  Pours a light golden with good carbonation, small white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, some light fruits.  Flavor of wheat, skunk, sweet malt.  I didn’t really like this and it had a funny taste that was sort of skunky.  Wouldn’t get again.
Bottle.  Light golden pour with tiny bubbles and a medium, frothy white head.  Sweet, caramel-malt aroma. Yeasty and malty with adequate hops.  Nice lager.

Bottle from World Market in Davis, CA.  Pours a pale golden color with a ton of carbonation. Thin while head that left an ample amount of lacing on the glass. Sweet aroma. Commericial description says there’s hops in the beer, but I didn’t really taste any. Pretty good beer, but not one I would drink on a regular basis.
Nice fruity aroma!  A small head upon pour and the beer settles quickly into a golden yellow color.  Good flavor and a nice easy finish.

I give it average all the way through because the taste didn’t overly impress me. However, on tap the it seems a little livelier. Pours a straw yellow colour, medium head. Aroma of corn, german hops and lemon. Taste is full on the palate, slightly bitter finish.
Bottle.  Pours a clear, gold color.  Small, bubbly white head.  Sweet aroma.  Nice medium body.  Crisp bready malt flavor.  Finish has a bit of hop bitterness.

An outstanding lager.  Pours a gorgeous although relatively light gold with a nice head and generous carbonation.  Nice balance betwee malt and hops - definitely not overly sweet.  I didn’t even get a trace of skunk, perhaps I got lucky.  I could drink a lot of these.  I enjoy all of my beer cold and keep a sixer of this on hand in a large bucket of ice water at all times.  I find this a better brew than Optimator although I’m sure I could find an argument from somebody on this.    Recommend highly.
Tasted much better on tap than when I had it out of the bottle.  Skunky aftertaste, reminded me of heineken.

Yellow gold, white small head that diminishes totally. Yeasty aroma pulls me away from the bottle at first. quite yeasty, sweet and sour. Very clear liquorice aftertaste. Very white wine -like with hops. feels like white wine with 15% alc. very strong. yeast bread malts on nose blown from mouth. Not so good but very interesting.

0.5l Bottle: 

Pours pale yellow-ish with a decent head. 

Pretty good for a lager, refreshing and reminds me a lot of the Stella you get on tap in Belgium (must better than UK Stella).
Bottle: Pours a clear gold with a white head. Aroma, grains, pale malts, yeast, grassy hops. Flavor, grains, yeast, sweet malts, grassy notes. Not bad.

500ml bottle.  golden clear and a little bit fizzy at first. sweet malty german beer smell. wheat and tiny hop action with honey
traces. light and crisp. drink outside at sunset on a redwood deck.
On tap @ Taco Mac.  Pours clear light golden, white head.  aroma of skunky hop.  flavor of crisp refreshing malt.  finishes with a bitter helles malt hop balance.  nice bitter finish.  Prost!
Bottle. Grassy, hoppy and vanilla notes. Pours a clear amber beer with a large white head and some carbonation. Taste is light, hoppy and typical of a lager/helles. Quite enjoyable.

This is a German beer and it tastes like one.  The same characteristic bite that many other German brew have, this one does too.  I honestly do not find it much different in taste that Beck’s or some of the other German lagers.
very carbonated, looks like champagne; strange skunky scent; very distinctive flavor with some bite, yet hard to describe; dry, bitter aftertaste
Easy to drink at first but after a while it gets harder to stand its bitter taste. A good head apearence and quite fizzy. Good flavor but not lasting.
16.9 0z. bottle, head looks like egg whites, golden color with very light hop flavor, save this for the summer

I enjoyed Spaten Premium Lager on tap at a Polish deli in Brooklyn, NY. Yellow in color, this beer has a very nice head and is full of carbonation. The aroma is very soft and the taste is very smooth with the wonderful taste of creamy malt. This was great with a corned beef sandwich!

Had this on tap at Murphy’s Logo Glass Night in Champaign, Illinois. Poured a vibrant yellow color with a small white head that disappeared quickly. The aroma consisted of grain, some light hops, and grass. The taste was nothing exciting... grainy flavor with a clean finish. I do not think I would have purchased this beer if the logo glass was not a boot-shaped glass. Oh, well... I now have another cool glass to add to my collection!
